awd_titl_txt: IUCRC Planning Grant Arizona State University: Center for Concrete Advanced Network - CAN
awd_abstract_narration:
The Concrete Advancement Network (CAN) is a consortium of academic and industrial researchers engaged in bringing cutting-edge technologies to the cement and concrete materials industries, improving the built environment. Cement and concrete represent ubiquitous human-made materials and continue to be widely utilized in construction. Despite a universal utilization, most modern cement and concrete applications are based on relatively dated technology, requiring massive inputs of raw materials. This IUCRC will allow researchers to collaborate on the latest advancements in nanotechnology, bottom-up engineering, recyclability, improved structural design with machine learning, and emergent technologies relating to the improvement of concrete in its use throughout the nation’s buildings and infrastructure. This award supports the planning phase of the CAN IUCRC to enable the team and participating leaders from industry to explore unmet needs, identify promising research trends, and formally establish the 5-year research plan for the proposed Center. The Planning Workshop will allow members and industry partners to establish the research agenda, select the first pool of research projects for the four member sites, and foster collaborative activities. CAN will be led by the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, with Arizona State University, Oregon State University, and the University of Texas at Arlington as partners. CAN’s members will facilitate the translation of novel concepts and ideas into scalable and implementable solutions with impact. Industry partners will steer CAN’s research direction and priorities to realization by providing testbeds and promoting CAN’s value proposition and research results to cement and concrete businesses.

CAN’s mission is to enhance the resilience and sustainability of concrete materials and structures through innovations in materials and processing by leveraging use-inspired research and collaborations between academia and related industrial partners. CAN will plan to develop new techniques and methods that will usher the next generation of concrete that is energy-efficient, rapidly deployable, labor efficient, economical, and less dependent on natural resources than existing concrete. The collaborative teams research capabilities will couple scientific advances in concrete materials and design with multi-scale modeling, machine learning, artificial intelligence, and, ultimately digital manufacturing, towards cutting-edge concepts in this critical and massive-scale industrial sector.  At the planning workshop and during the 12-month planning grant period, CAN industry and academic leaders will discuss current limitations, barriers, and obstacles to identify immediate solutions for industry/academic research and dissemination, engineering student education and job-preparedness, and broadening the participation of students underrepresented in STEM. CAN seeks to provide long-term solutions for the nation’s deteriorating infrastructure and meet the demand for future transportation, infrastructure, buildings, and housing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
Fundamental and applied research on concrete materials used in buildings and infrastructure is needed to overcome some of the most important challenges of the present society. This relates to advancing the service life and performance of cement-based materials in the built environment, the carbon footprint, as well as materials and design sustainability. Considering the enormous volume of the infrastructure development and maintenance in the next decades, developing the knowledge-base and workforce is required to ensure durable and sustainable concrete structures in varying environmental conditions. Advancing fundamental knowledge of cement-based materials is based on understanding the traditional design approaches by translating fundamental science towards a technology driven solution. The diversity of projects proposed range from several disciplines and include: nanomodification of microstructure for targeted performance,  understanding the spatio-temporal issues involved in digital fabrication, increasing the efficiency of consumption and big-data related to in-situ performance, to large-scale testing of hybrid reinforced concrete reveal the large scope and the potential impact of simple ideas such as increasing efficiency of concrete materials into the state-of-the-art.

 

The core objective of this effort was to identify areas of proposed research which are needed in an industrial setting to support the development of new manufacturing and alternative cement and composite systems.  The areas included, 3-D printing technology and formulations, low carbon cement formulations, Ultra-high performance concrete applications, reinforcing systems, and characterization of alternative structural designs. Many of the projects proposed are geared towards the implementation of alternative manufacturing and reinforcing systems in industry by paving the way for global changes and improvement in concrete technology. The interdisciplinary nature of materials science, structural mechanics, structural engineering, optimization, manufacturing technology, life cycle assessment, and mathematical modeling exemplifies the long-term commitment across the different fields.  These approaches contribute to solutions of a myriad of issues relevant to the progress of the society.

By streamlining the design and analysis tools, cooperation between academic and industry leaders and will open new areas of applied research to civil and construction engineers. Use of technologies such as Textile reinforced Concrete, hybrid reinforced concrete, and 3-D printing as well as structural shapes that are optimized for load carrying capacity are proposed. These approaches provide the best practices for rapid implementation of the developed innovations through the involvement of the consortium members in several code-and-standard writing bodies. The technology transfer effort is expected to enhance the competence of the partner industries, at the same time, acting as a mechanism to recruit new industrial partners to the consortium. One of our primary efforts is in manufacturing various systems for reinforced concrete structures to reduce reliance on using standard forming with rebar placement as the primary method of construction.  Through the development and dissemination of materials and processes that reduce the wasteful consumption of massive volumes of unreinforced concrete, that has no resistance to cracking, concrete efficiency, overall sustainability, and resilience is improved. 

The economic and societal relevance of this approach cannot be overstated. From a viewpoint of human resource development, one expects that those associated with the Center’s theme become new recruits for industrial positions construction materials.  Novel design areas will enhance the efficiency of structural design many folds. The industry can rely on the collaborating institutions not only as a technical resource, but also as a steady pipeline for trained professionals needed. 

 


Last Modified: 06/18/2024
Modified by: Barzin Mobasher
